item.title: Reflections on the Right Use of Artificial Intelligence With a View to the Love of Mathematics
item.description: Quentin Meillassoux’s speculative realism, launched with the provocative force of After Finitude, challenges the pervasive philosophical climate he terms “correlationism.” Correlationism insists that we only ever access the correlation between thinking and being, never either in isolation. Thought cannot grasp an object independent of its being-given-to-thought, nor conceive of a subject detached from its relation to an object. Meillassoux’s breaks free of this enclosure with the arche-fossil: scientific statements, like those dating the accretion of the Earth or the formation of stars, which refer to a reality chronologically anterior to the emergence of life and, consequently, anterior to any thought or consciousness. The arche-fossil presents a profound challenge: how can science meaningfully speak of a time when the correlation itself did not exist? How can a discourse meaningful for us, now, denote a reality radically independent of any us? The arche-fossil signifies a reality definitively not for us in its origin, yet seemingly accessed by us through mathematized science.
